question: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician because of ongoing shortness of breath, which is more prominent when he lies down. Occasionally, he experiences palpitations, especially during strenuous activities. In addition to this, he has been experiencing difficulty in digestion and often experiences regurgitation and dysphagia. He reports that he emigrated from Mexico 20 years ago and visits his hometown twice a year. The vital signs include: blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg, respiratory rate 19/min, and pulse 100/min. The physical examination shows jugular vein distention along with pitting edema in the ankles. Bilateral basilar crackles and an S3 gallop are heard on auscultation of the chest. A chest X-ray is taken. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no significant findings. What is the most likely explanation for this patientвЂ™s physical and diagnostic findings?

content.source_1: The patient presents with symptoms of shortness of breath that worsens when lying down, palpitations during activity, difficulty in digestion, regurgitation, dysphagia, jugular vein distention, pitting edema in the ankles, bilateral basilar crackles, and an S3 gallop. These findings suggest that the patient is suffering from congestive heart failure, which is supported by the S3 gallop and jugular venous distension. However, the difficulty in digestion and dysphagia indicate that there is an additional complication. The fact that the patient emigrated from Mexico and continues to visit frequently raises the possibility of Chagas disease, which is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. This disease is endemic in Latin America, including Mexico. Chagas disease can cause chronic heart problems including heart failure, arrhythmias, and can also affect the esophagus and colon causing difficulty in swallowing and digestion. The chronic form of Chagas disease leads to dilated cardiomyopathy which can be the underlying cause of the patientХs congestive heart failure and the esophageal symptoms.
content.source_2: The prior probability of constrictive pericarditis is about 2% in the general population. However, this patient is presenting with shortness of breath, especially when lying down, which is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis, increasing the probability to 10%. The palpitations during activity can also be attributed to constrictive pericarditis, further increasing the probability to 20%. The presence of difficulty in digestion along with regurgitation and dysphagia indicates impaired diastolic filling, which is seen in constrictive pericarditis, making the probability go up to 30%. The fact that the patient is from Mexico, where tuberculosis is endemic and tuberculosis is a cause of constrictive pericarditis, raises the probability to 50%. The physical examination shows jugular vein distention, pitting edema in the ankles, bilateral basilar crackles, and an S3 gallop which are classic signs of constrictive pericarditis, taking the probability to 70%. This patient most likely has constrictive pericarditis.
